title: Erdős Problem #792: Sum-Free Subsets
description: Estimate f(n), the minimum size of the largest sum-free subset guaranteed in any n-element set of integers.

overview.historicalContext: This problem is a cornerstone of additive combinatorics. Erdős established the basic n/3 lower bound. The problem appears as Problem 1 on Ben Green's open problems list. Recent work by Bedert (2025) achieved f(n) ≥ n/3 + c·log log n, while Eberhard-Green-Manners established f(n) ≤ n/3 + o(n).
overview.problemStatement: A set B ⊆ ℤ is sum-free if there are no a, b, c ∈ B with a + b = c. Let f(n) be the maximum value such that every n-element subset A ⊆ ℤ contains a sum-free subset B with |B| ≥ f(n). Estimate f(n).
overview.proofStrategy: The lower bound uses probabilistic and algebraic methods. The 'middle third' construction shows f(n) ≥ n/3. Improvements use Fourier analysis and additive combinatorics techniques. The upper bound constructs explicit sets with small sum-free subsets.
keyInsights: The main term is n/3, achieved by the 'middle third' construction
The second-order term is the key open question
Bedert's 2025 result: f(n) ≥ n/3 + c·log log n
The exact growth rate of f(n) - n/3 remains unknown

sections.title: Sum-Free Sets
sections.content: A set B is sum-free if a + b ≠ c for all a, b, c ∈ B. Equivalently, B ∩ (B + B) = ∅. The condition prevents any element from being expressible as the sum of two others in the set.

sections.title: The Function f(n)
sections.content: f(n) is defined as the minimum, over all n-element sets A ⊆ ℤ, of the maximum size of a sum-free subset of A. We seek both upper and lower bounds on f(n).

sections.title: Lower Bounds
sections.content: Erdős: f(n) ≥ n/3. Alon-Kleitman: f(n) ≥ (n+1)/3. Bourgain: f(n) ≥ (n+2)/3. Bedert (2025): f(n) ≥ n/3 + c·log log n. These progressively improve the second-order term.

sections.title: Upper Bounds
sections.content: Eberhard-Green-Manners: f(n) ≤ n/3 + o(n). This shows the main term n/3 is optimal. Combined with lower bounds, we have f(n)/n → 1/3 as n → ∞.

sections.title: Main Open Question
sections.content: What is the exact second-order term? Is f(n) = n/3 + Θ(log log n)? The gap between the Bedert lower bound and Eberhard-Green-Manners upper bound remains the key open problem.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #792 asks for the asymptotics of f(n), the guaranteed size of sum-free subsets. We know f(n)/n → 1/3, but the second-order term remains open. Recent progress by Bedert achieved f(n) ≥ n/3 + c·log log n.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would illuminate the structure of sum-free sets and extremal problems in additive combinatorics. The problem connects to Ramsey theory and Schur numbers.
openQuestions: Is f(n) = n/3 + Θ(log log n)?
What sets A achieve the minimum f(n)?
Can Bedert's lower bound be improved?
Is there a matching upper bound of n/3 + O(log log n)?
